Valle Vista is part of a larger healthcare organization with acute care hospitals, addiction care hospitals, and behavioral health programs all over the United States. They also offer training programs for director level positions. There is a 401k with a company match.
cons: Just like any addiction and behavioral health setting, the work can be stressful. Valle Vista does its best to create a welcoming and safe environment for all patients and employees. Time is spent training employees on how to handle situations that may arise on the units so employees feel confident and prepared.

pros: I would have to say that the biggest pro for me was my coworkers. They always had my back, and I knew I could count on them when things got rough. Which they always did.
cons:
I don’t even know where to begin with this. First off the biggest thing wrong with this company is their management. Unless you are buddy buddy or in the clique, you will never matter. There are some employees who can get away with sitting behind the nurses station their entire shift while other ones are out busting their butts with patients. It’s definitely not hard to tell which people are managements favorites.
Also, be careful when you try to stick up for yourself. Management has been known to be vindictive and spiteful and punish people for trying to stick up for themselves. 
The ratio between patients and staff is horrendous. There are always high acuity patients, and management refuses to take acuity into consideration when staffing. Many times if you ask for help you were just told flat out no. Then, you will get punished for even asking for help.
They will expect you to pick up a ton of extra shifts. If you say no they get extremely irritated with you. For them it’s no big deal for someone to work back to back 16 hour shifts. I have even seen them approve vacation time for someone, and call them and cancel their vacation the night before because they didn’t have enough staff to cover it. 
The pay sucks. You do get raises every year, but they’re anywhere from $.03-$.40.

review_title: If your options are be unemployed or work at Valle, stick with unemployment
pros: Used to be the people -- now all the good ones are mostly gone
cons:
Where do we start... 

HR is shady... They conveniently "lose" most of the paperwork that you turn into them. When I first started there, I turned in paperwork for direct deposit - two months later when I was still receiving a paper check, HR just had to say that my bank (whom I've been with the last 10 years) wasn't accepting my information and I'd have to resubmit. That's Valle's HR code for "We lost your paper"... Then we go to the matter of my orientation packet. I turned it in after my 6 shifts of orientation were completed - a year later when they were having HR files reviewed by corporate they realized mine wasn't in there and demanded I come to work and fill it out before they auditors arrived. Oh, and I've probably had 5 TB tests in the two years that I worked there because HR doesn't know how to file. 

Lets move on to job. I'm an RN -- the pay sucks. You start out around $24ish an hour plus there's shift difs. The amount they pay you and the amount of work and crap you're expected to deal with are not even in the same galaxy. You have an EXTREMELY high rate of patient turnovers. On Mondays and Fridays, the heaviest with discharges and subsequently admissions, you could see 20+ leave and then fill right back up. When I first started, they didn't have an admissions nurse, which they have hired and that's helped some but for the two nurses and LPN working the books it's a mess... The patients can speak to you any way they please. They can stand at that window and cuss you out and you cannot really say anything to them because HR and the CEO will fire you in the blink of an eye. I have been on more than one occasion threatened and there is no one to call - no one will help you or stand up for you. They have rules on the unit, but if you break them, there are no consequences. Prime example is smoking. You'll have a multitude of patients that get cigarettes at visitation or try and smuggle them in during their admission and they'll smoke in their rooms. You catch them violating a clear hospital policy which has been explained to them on more than one occasion and then what happens - NOTHING. Why even make these rules if there's not going to be any consequences for violating them? Patient ratios... These are constantly at an unsafe ratio... You have one nurse to about 21 adult psych/detoxing patients. People that need monitored that you can't monitor because you're too busy getting yelled at by the patient that wants to leave AMA and the doc won't call you back. If your patient acuity goes up - your staffing does not reflect that. Detoxing patients and psych patients have no business being placed on the same unit and in the same rooms. They're needs are not even remotely in the same ballpark.. They will admit until they have all the beds full and then you're left to try and figure out the mess that has been created for you. If you don't have a bed, they will admit to an observation room which I'm pretty sure is illegal. Sometimes both your observation rooms will have patients in them and if there's a crisis situation you're screwed because you have no place left to go to provide care. 

As far as providing care, you are just a pill pusher more than anything. Drug them up, give them Suboxone which most of them tell you they just leave and sell their scripts. You aren't making any kind of difference, you're just part of the problem. 

You can't tell anyone in any kind of management roles your frustration because they will guilt trip you and use your words against you. I loved working in psych but I would not recommend Valle Vista to ANYONE seeking a job OR treatment.
